Content:: In church architecture, a retroquire (also spelled retrochoir), or back-choir,[1] is the space behind the high altar in a church or cathedral, which sometimes separates it from the end chapel. It may contain seats for the church choir.[2] An example of a retroquire is within Winchester Cathedral, which was built between 1200 and 1230 to house a shrine for Saint Swithun.[3]  This article about the architecture of churches or other Christian places of worship is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. This architectural element–related article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.
